instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00281: What is 820-00281? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PM_SLP_SUS_L:
What is PM_SLP_SUS_L? 
The "PM_SLP_SUS_L" signal in a MacBook is related to the power management of the device, specifically concerning the 'suspend to RAM' state or S3 state. It's an active-low signal that, when asserted (low voltage), indicates the system should enter or is in the S3 sleep state. .
definitions.PP1V8_SUS: What is PP1V8_SUS? PP1V8_SUS is a 1.8v power rail active in a suspend state..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message:
I'm working on <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board which is not turning on. Customer states, that it just died with no reason. There is no liquid or physical damage, no corrosion, no other repair attempts. Board switches to 20V but gets stuck at 0,04A. The <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> are missing, no shorts. Also <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_SUS_L</SIGNAL> is low with 0,003V. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12,57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3,41V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> - 3,30V

<CHIP>U7800</CHIP> and the area around looks really good, but I have replaced it just on case with no result. 

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_PMIC</SIGNAL> - 12,57V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_PMICLDO</SIGNAL> - 3,29V
<SIGNAL>PP5V_PMICLDO</SIGNAL> - 5,00V

On thermal camera I can see, that PCH get slightly warmer in two areas amd my guess is PCH is dead. Maybe you have other suggestions?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message:
PCH should be cold in this stage.
Check diode mode to ground on all coils, especially PCH and CPU; compare with good board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message: After I have posted this thread I have discovered, that <SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>PP1V_PCH_REG_R</SIGNAL> are shorted - 0,000V in diode mode and 0,001 Ohm. If I inject 1V, board takes ~0,3 - 0,5A but nothing really gets warm, even PCH. I have lifted up L8000 and short appers to be at PCH side.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message:
Two power rails shorted denote a problem with the common point, PCH.
You can't heat anything with 0.5W; maybe IR camera sees very small difference between PCH and rest of the MLB.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message: Yes, I'm going to replace PCH and clean ME region in BIOS.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message: So I have replaced PCH, both <SIGNAL>PP1V0_SUS</SIGNAL> / <SIGNAL>PP1V_PCH_REG_R</SIGNAL> lines are now present, nothing shorted. Board starts, CPU VCORE is present, all S0 voltages too but there is no video, no chime, just clicking trackpad. Board takes ~1A from charger. I have already tried new bios found on this forum, but it hasn't changed anything. Could you please share known 100% working bios with clean ME?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00281</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no SUS voltages
threads.message: Ok, with this BIOS everything works, problem solved. Thank you [USER=682]@2informaticos[/USER] for your help.
